citations.narrative:
** The licensee transported a female spider monkey named Brazil. From Texas to Michigan for delivery on 09-10-2024.
The licensee could not provide evidence that a health certificate was issued for the transport of the non-human primate.
No USDA licensed person shall transport, in commerce a non-human primate unless accompanied by a valid health
certificate. This is to ensure that such animal is free of any infectious disease or other physical abnormality that could
endanger the animal, other animals or the public health. The licensee must have a valid health certificate for regulated
dogs, cats and non-human primates transported in commerce. To be corrected by: 10-23-2024.

citations.desc: Procurement of dogs, cats, and other animals; dealers.
citations.narrative:
** The licensee on 09-10-2024 exchanged one female spider monkey named Brazil, for one black and white male
capuchin named Ozzy. This transaction was conducted with an unlicensed facility. The transfer of a non-human primate in
exchange for compensation is regulated activity and requires a USDA license. The licensee obtained a non-human
primate from an unlicensed source.
Procurement of non-human primates from unlicensed facilities limits traceability of animals and prevents APHIS officials
from ensuring that the Animal Welfare Act regulations are met and to provide for the health and well-being of the animals.
The licensee must not procure animals from individuals or facilities that are required to be licensed by the USDA.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with licensee.
n

narrative:
2.78(a) 
   
Health certification and identification. 
** The licensee transported a female spider monkey named Brazil. From Texas to Michigan for delivery on 09-10-2024. 
The licensee could not provide evidence that a health certificate was issued for the transport of the non-human primate. 
No USDA licensed person shall transport, in commerce a non-human primate unless accompanied by a valid health 
certificate. This is to ensure that such animal is free of any infectious disease or other physical abnormality that could 
endanger the animal, other animals or the public health. The licensee must have a valid health certificate for regulated 
dogs, cats and non-human primates transported in commerce. To be corrected by: 10-23-2024. 
2.132(d)  Critical Repeat
   
Procurement of dogs, cats, and other animals; dealers. 
** The licensee on 09-10-2024 exchanged one female spider monkey named Brazil, for one black and white male 
capuchin named Ozzy. This transaction was conducted with an unlicensed facility. The transfer of a non-human primate in 
exchange for compensation is regulated activity and requires a USDA license. The licensee obtained a non-human 
primate from an unlicensed source. 
Procurement of non-human primates from unlicensed facilities limits traceability of animals and prevents APHIS officials 
from ensuring that the Animal Welfare Act regulations are met and to provide for the health and well-being of the animals. 
The licensee must not procure animals from individuals or facilities that are required to be licensed by the USDA. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with licensee.
